subject: To Blog, or Not to Blog
event:
Robin Hobb Speaks Truth: http://robinhobb.com/rant.html

Reading this was painful.  Hits too close to home.

Maybe I have to start posting here less often.

comments.article: I don't think blogging is the problem... spending hours reading OTHER blogs is the problem... but that's just me.

Indeed. To some extent, a "real" blog is better than LJ for that reason - its so much easier to avoid clicking on commenters and finding out who they are.

OTOH, Robin Hobb could learn a lot from blogging. For example, she could learn how to write what she means with more clarity and expression, so that I dont have to struggle to get through her books. She is so much harder to read than most other authors!

(imo the Liveship trilogy was much better than either Fitz series, simply because it was so much easier to read)
Real Life needn't be real and there are many places where the internet may die. Go, run to this place George and keep hope.
all things in moderation, i say.

Time can be squandered in a number of ways. LJ can be a pleasant diversion instead of a time waster.

Besides, how else would I know how your cats were doing? Or what you've named the kitten?

It depends what you do with your blog, I suppose. Surely, you need an outlet that isn't work, but does involve writing?

Maybe it's easy to cast stones as someone who doesn't write for a living, but if a writer doesn't have the discipline to restrict their time online, then they don't have the discipline to write professionally at all?

comments.upictitle: Ansem, seeker of the cock: Kain
comments.article:
In my opinion, blogging is the symptom, not the actual disease. If you're not blogging, you might be browsing forums or youtube, or wikipedia instead. And if you instead prohibit yourself from the internet, then you might be distracted by television or books or the radio.

If people can't keep yourself on task as badly as that rant implies, then nothing short of locking themselves in a completely bare room for eight hours a day will truly help. Some people might find blogging more addicting than anything else, but give it ten years, and people will invent something that might be even more addicting.

It's not that limiting your time spent blogging is a bad idea, but it's in the same way that you limit your time spent reading or surfing the rest of the internet in general. Blogging isn't any new demon or anything, just a new face of the old one.
Hear, hear!

Self-control and willpower are the key. Just need to know yourself and lay off accordingly.
Other authors I know blog near daily and get through books just fine and it gives them an outlet when things may not be going so well. Besides, it also gives that extra connection with the fans that I can say is appreciated on this end.

Um, Robin's 'rants' are meant to be tongue-in-cheek and over-the-top. If you navigated her site to find the rant, you'd discover it's behind a picture of a 'mad woman in the attic'. So don't take it too seriously, because it isn't meant to be too serious. After all, Robin has a blog. :-D

comments.article:
i haven't read the link, but the truth is we all go through this.

author, writer, singer, artist, father, child, pet rock. doesn't matter. we all try to decide whether the LJ is for real and worth our time.

I, for one, love cursing your ability to kill off all my loves after our first dates then wonder how the hell you can live with yourself as a proponent of that lamb-faced pawn Mr. Manning.

i, for one, am in no rush to read the next book in the series. when it's done, it's done. if it's not LJ, it's something else. if it's not something else, it's that other thing. then it's this again. Who knows? It doesn't matter in the long run. You'll do it when you're ready.

If you use LJ for what it's intended - describing and working through your own thoughts and resist the urge to make it a medium through which to communicate with the smoky masses outside your own skin, you'll be fine.

but that's just me. and i need to not get that last beer out of the fridge and go to bed.

...I just noticed you have a new LJ layout...

As kativy has said, all things in moderation. :)

I definitely can see where Hobb is coming from. I no longer keep a paper journal since I started LJ. On paper I wrote creatively, on the computer I don't. All of my poetry has dried up. I do miss it, but I can't seem to pry myself away from LJ.

I too stopped keeping my composition book journals once I realized that I journal much more here than there.  I don't know if I have suffered a lack of creativity, but I do understand the allure of LJ.

Personally.. I think that your blog and the blogs of the other writers I enjoy reading are a great inspiration. It gives some insight into the *person* who wrote the stories I so much enjoy reading. Being a part of TarValon.net... the passing of Robert Jordan was felt by all of us as the passing of a dear friend. In part, because we interacted with him on his blog at Dragonmount and through it we shared in some small way what he was going through in his life. It made us more aware of the particular condition he struggled with. It also inspired us with his unflagging courtesy and courage.

I do not think a blog need be a waste of time in any way. I really believe it can be a source of connection and inspiration.. for the blogger and the reader.

I come here to read about progress on the new books, not to read about who won the super bowl or something. I do think blogging, micro blogging etc. are addictive and could hold a person from his real-life tasks.

If you think your blogging activities are holding you from writing, then please stop blogging. I would really prefer a completed series of books over some irrelevant blogging, that I can find everywhere on the internet ;-)
Yes, because writers are only passionate about their jobs and shouldn't have any outside interests that might take precious minutes away from providing you with entertainment.

comments.article: Thank you for saying everything I wanted to.
Well, there are often long periods without any entry in your LJ. Do you work better, then ? I think the answer is there, whatever it is.

I respect Robin's opinion on this. I know she closed down her forum because she felt she had to be too involved in discussions. That said, I think the tone of it seems too absolutist. Not every writer gets as stuck on writing on their blog instead of writing on their next story as Hobb suggests.

The most obvious example is Neil Gaiman, who blogs just about every day, and often answers two or three e-mails from fans and acquaintances in the course of those blog posts. When it's time for him to get cracking on a new project, though, he'll go into seclusion (quite literally, sometimes, when he hides out in a cabin in the woods without so much as a cell phone signal).

John Scalzi obviously posts quite a bit, and I'm not sure how he manages to turn out books while he's doing it, but somehow he manages it. And he has comments on his blogs which he responds to directly, too, unlike Gaiman; I'm guessing he's just really good at switching from blogging-mode to writing-mode, whereas many writers find it easier to focus on one thing intensely and prefer no distractions. Ultimately, only the writer can judge.

A number of blogging writers I know of go the Gaiman route, really. They announce they're taking a break from blogging for x weeks/months, and that often seems to work for people.

I suppose there is the angle that even in the case of a Gaiman or a Scalzi, if they didn't blog, they'd be more productive professionally. That's a very dangerous perspective, because if they enjoy it and see it to some degree as a fun hobby, who's to say they can't do it? Writers need their hobbies and their fun, too, or they'll burn out. (Well, most of them do, anyways; I'm suspicious of certain authors.)

While I'm sure everyone who reads your posts appreciates the insight into the life of one of their favourite authors, those are the same people who are champing at the bit when it comes to being able to spend their money on your next book. If you were to restrict yourself to 1 a post per week/fortnight/month in the name of getting your projects completed quicker (even for a set period as a trial to see whether you're able to get more of your book written that way), I don't think the complaints would be too loud.

comments.article:
It's an interesting point.
I used to keep a blog, and 2 livejournals (One as a private diary)
The blog was for non-livejournal using friends, although I tended to re-write everything rather than just copying and pasting.

It's amazing how much more writing you get done when you aren't blogging.
Best to keep it simple and just have one work blog and maybe a facebook for your friends to keep in touch.

that said a large part of writing comes from the need to tell people things. But I can't help but wonder that if half the bloggers stopped and applied the same energies to writing professionally then we might get a lot more quality journalism in the world.
